title: What does the statement "Your browser is being managed by your organization." mean at the top of my Options page?  I don't have an 'organization'.
content:
There have been times when I think that an outside source is directing my computer to places I don't want it to go. There are also times when a link within a news site will not go to the news story I expect it to go. There are other times when my screen saver has been removed and just the blue Windows default screen is there. I have to go into [Control Panel] and re-select the picture file I wish it to draw images from for display. There are other anomalies too that seem to be not of my doing. These are all recent, within a couple of months. I use Avast Virus software and Malwarebytes software too. Also, as of two days ago there are ads popping up on every news site I watch. I did have an ad blocker program running but it would appear to not be working.

However, that statement 'Your browser is being managed by your organization.' is making me concerned. Can you explain statement that to me?

Also, while I'm here I have another question. I have been using Firefox since the end of Netscape Navigator and once upon a time any desktop shortcut icons were all Firefox's icon. Then for years they turned into Internet Explorer icons. When I clicked on the shortcuts Explorer would open and I don't like that program. So now I click on an icon's [Properties] and copy the url and paste it into Firefox's search window. But within the last month the icons are now Google's Chrome image. I don't understand why, if Firefox is my default browser, these icon changes occur. And why Chrome? Is it because I have Google's search engine as the default search engine?

I appreciate any help you can provide to me. Thanks!

Mike Moore e-mail: xxxxxxxx@xxxxxxxx.xx.xx

(email address removed by moderator; please do not post personal information on a public website; Forum rules and guidelines)
creator: mickmoor

title: Site information (security / lock icon menu) not displaying correctly in Nightly
content:
So this visual bug has been happening on my Nightly install for months now. The "Site information for website.com" menu that appears when you click the lock icon in the address bar is basically unusable for me. The menu's header, "clear cookies" button, and arrow button are all fine, but the text in between is covered in globe icons. The "Connection Security" sub-menu that the arrow leads to has a similar case. (See screenshot.)

Huge disclaimer: I am using Shadowfox, which modifies a Firefox install to make UI elements darker. It has made text difficult to read for me at times, but it has never produced any really strange artifacts like this one as far as I can tell. I do have a Developer Edition install with no Shadowfox and it doesn't have the issue. However, maybe this is a common Nightly issue. (I guess this wouldn't make sense since DE is even more experimental than Nightly? I think?)

Maybe this is a problem for the Shadowfox team. Ultimately, the solution I really want is native support for a full-fledged dark mode, with black or gray color for UI elements such as the context menu. If this isn't going to happen and Shadowfox is indeed the source of the issue, I'll gladly let them know. But I thought it would be good to share with Mozilla, and why not the community, too. (Feedback tool is down right now.)

title: hard to find Firefox bug reporting procedure
content:
I got a new little start-up error from Firefox (I only have one GPU - AMD/ATI RV620 FirePro 2450):

$ firefox [GFX1-]: More than 1 GPU detected via PCI, cannot deduce vendor [GFX1-]: PCI candidate 0x1002/0x95cd [GFX1-]: PCI candidate 0x1002/0x95cd

I want to report this new little Firefox bug. I used the Firefox menu "Help | Submit Feedback" but it tells me:

"Please check back soon: We've paused submissions to this form so that we can improve how we collect feedback. Looking for support for Firefox or another product from Mozilla? Just head to Support.Mozilla.org"

Many people would stop right there, but I kept trying.

As instructed, I went to https://support.mozilla.org/ and got the "Search Support" page.

I used ^F and searched for the word "bug" on that page. Nothing. I searched for "report" and only found "Report Trademark Abuse".

Many people would stop right there, but I kept trying.

Under "Get Help" I selected "Firefox" which led me here to "Firefox Support":

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/products/firefox

I again ^F searched for the word "bug" on that page. Nothing. I again searched for "report" and only found "Report Trademark Abuse".

Many people would stop right there, but I kept trying.

In the search box I typed "how do I report a Firefox bug". The top item on the first page of 246 pages returned was "How do I submit a bug for Firefox Sync?" but nothing about reporting a bug for Firefox itself.

Many people would stop right there, and I did.

Nobody is going to go looking through the other 245 pages of search results to find out how.

Why do you make it so hard to report a Firefox bug? Why isn't the answer to that obvious question the top search result on the Firefox Support page? Why do I even need to search for it at all -- it should be right on the page: "How to report a bug in Firefox"

(NOTE: This is not a request asking how to report the bug. I know how. This is a request asking you to fix the web site so that *finding* how to report a bug is easier. Much easier. If you want a great product, make it easy for your users to give you feedback.) I should probably submit this via Bugzilla but you disabled my account due to "inactivity" so I can't.

title: Disfunctional Browser wont open links (random), download page contents or allow wireless connections
content:
The problem has been going on for a few weeks now and I have the feeling the disfunction is related to an update. I tried whatever fixes I could understand in the troubleshooting guide to no avail (Clearing cache, reset firefox, ensure it's up to date, safe mode, disable add-ons, disabled security...). New pages will open and sometimes I get a partial download of a bannerhead but then the circle goes on endlessly. The download will stop and If I constantly refresh I might eventually get to the page. I checked with Verizon, my ISP, and they say they see no problem on their end. My Alexa got disconnected and I tried unsuccessfully, with Amazon assistance to reconnect it but whenever I connected it to my wireless, my wireless woould disconnect. Then if I tried to connect my wireless, the Amazon connection would disconnect. This has been going on for weeks and at the point where I feel my only option is to give up on Firefox cause of a sense that it's gone overboard with its security protections for non-ecperts on computers. I've been troubleshooting this for hours and hours over 10 days and I'm at my wits end.

I have an up to date Firefox andI'm operating a windows 10 computer.

Sometimes I get error messages. I've gotten this one: 502 ERROR The request could not be satisfied. The origin closed the connection. We can't connect to the server for this app or website at this time. There might be too much traffic or a configuration error. Try again later, or contact the app or website owner. If you provide content to customers through CloudFront, you can find steps to troubleshoot and help prevent this error by reviewing the CloudFront documentation.

Generated by cloudfront (CloudFront)

or (after about 10 seconds) 504 - Gateway Timeout

I've gotten one while trying to sign into Firefox to write this but can only copy one message. This one was different - not from CloudFront -- but it too said something about the site being too busy to connect as one possible reason for the failure.

Any possible explainations/solutions before I have to abandon the browser? I don't want too as I appreciate the security but if the price is I can't function on the computer what choice have I.
creator: TimOD

title: Proton UI doesn't work in Firefox 87 (Stable)
content:
SYSTEM SPECS: OS: Windows 7 System Type: 64-bit Operating System RAM: 2 GB Firefox Version: 87.0 (64-bit Installation)

I want to try the new Proton UI for Firefox. I followed all these steps: 1. Go to "about:config". 2. Search for "proton" and set the "browser.proton.enabled" from false to true. 3. Restart Firefox.

creator: erickcgart

title: [Solved] FF87.0 font issue
content:
FF87.0 on Win10, all addons deactivated.

Hi, it seems that over night, the font of Japanese text in my MediaWiki has changed from [this](https://i.imgur.com/fxV9rMr.png) to [this](https://i.imgur.com/1uI9c1h.png). I don't know why, since I didn't access the server files or changed anything around.

Over the course of troubleshooting, I figured out that it seems like the monospaced font is at fault. So I tried to change the font Firefox uses for *serif fonts* to MS Gothic (instead of standard TNR). This is despite using *monospaced font* in my user settings on the wiki.

I also opened FF on my laptop where it is still on 84.0.2 and everything looks as it should, with the same standard settings applied everywhere. So I'm 80% sure the last FF updated changed something. The missing 20% are because I only noticed this yesterday, but the update happened four days ago, right?

Also, on the old FF the fonts used are Courier New and Microsoft YaHei. On the new FF it's Courier New and SimSun. In the settings I have "Fonts for: Latin" and the standard fonts, so I don't know where YaHei and SimSun come from. When I change Serif: TNR to YaHei, it changes from SimSun to YaHei...

Edit: This thread solved it, actually: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1277075

Short answer: Add Japanese to the preferred languages, leave everything else as it is.
creator: denito666

title: All pages are blank, including about:config and about:preferences
content:
Firefox can't load any page, including about:config and about:preferences. about:support is working. All menus and surrounding UI is working too, but, for example, if I try to open Preferences page from menu - it will not open, even new tab isn't created.

If I start firefox with MOZ_DISABLE_CONTENT_SANDBOX=1 all works fine. Problem appeared after I accidentally used all of my laptop RAM with other app. Firefox didn't crashed, but after reopening this issue is began appearing.

I use Linux Mint 20, and apt-upgraded all packages (including firefox) right after this issue first appeared. I tried to: - restart browser (didn't work) - restart laptop (didn't work) - use different profile (didn't work) - use browser safe mode (didn't work) - clear caches (didn't work) - disable all extensions (didn't work) - use different versions: 75.0, 87.0, 82.0, freshly-compiled by myself (didn't work) - refreshing firefox (didn't work) - run firefox with MOZ_DISABLE_CONTENT_SANDBOX=1 (worked, but it's obviously unsafe and don't fix the root problem)

I found some issues and bugs that looks pretty similar to mine: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1245935 https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1235332 https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1279656 https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1433065

Also, after closing firefox, it stays running in processes, and I can't open new window for 30 seconds or more after closing old window.

I think it's bug and problem is somewhere in firefox sources. Do you have any ideas, how can I fix this?
